title: 112_hr3429
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rigs to Reefs Habitat Protection Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "Rigs to Reefs Habitat Protection Act," defines key terms such as decommissioning, Fund, Notice, and platform, which refers to offshore oil and gas platforms in the Gulf of Mexico no longer useful for operations but critical for marine fisheries habitat. The "Rigs to Reefs Habitat Protection Act" defines key terms and establishes the artificial reef program for offshore oil and gas platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, critical for marine fisheries habitat. The Program is authorized under the National Fishing Enhancement Act of 1984, and the Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. USE OF OFFSHORE OIL AND GAS PLATFORMS FOR ARTIFICIAL REEFS. The Secretary must assess platforms to determine coral populations, protected species, and species with recreational or commercial value. Platforms cannot be removed until assessments are completed, and decommissioning may be suspended if a substantial reef ecosystem is found nearby. The decommissioning of a platform may be placed on hold if it could harm the reef ecosystem. Lessees can be exempt from removing a platform if they commit to entering it into an artificial reef program. Reefing in place and state programs are also allowed under the Program. Under the Program, a State with a rig-to-reef program can assume liability for structures in Federal waters. The operator remains responsible for maintenance. Top decks of rigs can be removed down to water level with markers for navigation. Owners must maintain an anode system and contribute to a fund for inclusion in the Program. The Reef Maintenance Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to maintain artificial reefs under the Program. Owners must pay 50 percent of removal costs if they participate in the Program. Amounts in the Fund can only be used for reef maintenance purposes. The Reef Maintenance Fund is established to maintain artificial reefs under the Program. Owners must pay 50 percent of removal costs if they participate. The Fund can only be used for reef maintenance purposes. The Secretary must submit annual reports on the Fund's operation to specific committees. The Reef Maintenance Fund is used for reef maintenance purposes. The annual report must include expenditures, recommendations for additional authorities, and the remaining balance in the Fund.
